New Records: Germany secured their largest-ever win in a Euro opener with a 5-1 victory over Scotland.
Thomas Müller became the oldest player to score in a Euro match for Germany at 34 years old.
Florian Wirtz became the youngest player to score in a Euro match for Germany at 17 years old.
Key Match Events: Germany scored four goals in the first half, the fastest any team has achieved in Euro history.
Scotland were reduced to 10 men after Ryan Porteous received a red card for a two-footed challenge on Ilkay Gundogan.
Kai Havertz converted a penalty after a VAR review following Musiala's foul.
Niclas Füllkrug scored twice on his debut after coming on as a substitute.
Emre Can scored the fifth goal in the final minute of the match.
Pre-Game Insights: Germany coach Julian Nagelsmann emphasized his players' hunger to atone for recent failures and expressed confidence in their ability to win the tournament.
Scotland coach Steve Clarke urged his players to 'fear no one' as they aimed to end their 22-year Euro absence with a win.
Post-Match Reflections: Germany manager Julian Nagelsmann praised the team's performance and expressed optimism about their title chances.
Toni Kroos hinted at retiring from international football after the tournament, though he played a key role in the match.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The match was held in Munich, Germany, as they hosted the Euro 2024 tournament.
Despite heavy rain earlier in the day, the game was played without significant weather disruptions.
